name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
definition: A collection of infrastructure services started by one of the largest e-commerce companies in the world

name: Application Programming Interface (API)
definition: The interface in which we interact with a code base or application

name: Asynchronous JavaScript and XML (AJAX)
definition: A way of asynchronously making requests to servers from the client

name: Behavior Driven Development (BDD)
definition: A development strategy focusing on writing tests with readable sentences some times based on user stories

name: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS)
definition: The language used to give an HTML page its visual style

name: Command-line Interface (CLI)
definition: The generic name for Terminal, Shell, Bash, etc.

name: Content Delivery Network (CDN)
definition: A server or servers dedicated to hosting static content, optimized for performance

name: Continuous Delivery (CD)
definition: A software engineering approach in which teams produce software in short cycles, ensuring that the software can be reliably released at any time

name: Continuous Integration (CI)
definition: The practice of merging all developer working copies to a shared mainline several times a day

name: Create Read Update Delete (CRUD)
definition: A set of four common actions performed on data

name: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)
definition: A browser implemented security feature to allow or deny making requests from one domain to another.

name: Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF)
definition: An attack that forces an end user to execute unwanted actions on a web application in which they're currently authenticated, specifically state-changing requests

name: Cross-site Scripting (XSS)
definition: A security breach that takes advantage of dynamically generated web pages rendering JavaScript from a users input

name: Database (DB)
definition: A collection of information that is organized so it can be easily accessed, managed and updated

name: Database Management System (DBMS)
definition: A general-purpose software system for the definition, creation, querying, update, and administration of databases

name: Dependency Injection (DI)
definition: A technique whereby one object supplies the dependencies of another object

name: Document Object Model (DOM)
definition: A representation of an HTML Document converted into a programmable interface

name: Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY)
definition: A principle of software development aimed at reducing repetition of software patterns or duplicate code

name: End 2 End Tests (e2e)
definition: A type of test to ensure functionality works from start to finish

name: Entity Relationship Diagram (ERD)
definition: A data modeling technique that graphically illustrates an information system's entities and the relationships between those entities

name: File-transfer Protocol (FTP)
definition: A standard network protocol used for the transfer of computer files between a client and server

name: Higher-Order Component (HOC)
definition: A function that takes a component and returns a new component

name: Higher-Order Function (HOF)
definition: A function that takes functions as arguments, or returns a function as its result

name: Hyper-Text Transfer Protocol (HTTP)
definition: An application protocol for distributed, collaborative, and hypermedia information systems which is also the foundation of data communication for the World Wide Web

name: Immediately-invoked Function Expression (IIFE)
definition: A wrapping function we invoke on definition to prevent new variables from being exposed to the current scope

name: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)
definition: A business selling virtualized computing resources on a subscription

name: Integrated Development Environment (IDE)
definition: Software to ease the pain of writing code manually, usually geared towards a specific language or languages

name: Internet of Things (IoT)
definition: A reference to the ever-growing network of physical objects that feature an IP address for internet connectivity

name: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON)
definition: A data format commonly used on the web to exchange data between servers or store in a standardized format.

name: JSON Web Tokens (JWT)
definition: A way for us to store JSON data in a "token" format, meaning it will have a tamper evident check involved

name: Keep It Simple, Stupid (KISS)
definition: A principle stating that most systems work best if they are kept simple rather than made complicated

name: Model View Controller (MVC)
definition: An architectural pattern to divide an application into three interconnected parts to keep data, visual, and intermediary code separated

name: Node Package Manager (npm)
definition: A package manager for JavaScript, also the world's largest software registry

name: Platform as a Service (PaaS)
definition: A business selling cloud computing as a subscription

name: PostgreSQL (PSQL)
definition: An open source relational database management system based on traditional SQL, also referred to as `pg`

name: Pull Request (PR)
definition: A request to merge changes from another branch or repository on Github

name: Quality Assurance (QA)
definition: A means of monitoring the software engineering processes and methods used to ensure quality through automated or manual testing

name: Regular Expression (RegEx)
definition: A sequence of characters that define a search pattern

name: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG)
definition: An XML-based markup language for describing two dimensional based vector graphics.

name: Secure Shell (SSH)
definition: A network protocol for connecting to networked services in a secure manner

name: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)
definition: The standard for creating a secure link between the web and browser

name: Semantic Versioning (SemVer)
definition: A versioning spec that uses the format `major.minor.patch` (e.g. `1.3.1`)

name: Single-page Application (SPA)
definition: An application that serves from a single page (often `index.html`) and may include client-side routing.

name: Software as a Service (SaaS)
definition: A business who sells a subscription to proprietary software

name: S.O.L.I.D. Principles (SOLID)
definition: A mnemonic acronym for five design principles intended to make software designs more understandable, flexible and maintainable

name: Structured Query Language (SQL)
definition: A standardized programming language used for managing and performing various operations on data in relational databases

name: Syntactically Awesome Style Sheets (SASS)
definition: A style sheet language allowing variables, nested rules, mixins, and more on top of CSS

name: Test Driven Development (TDD)
definition: A software development process that relies on writing tests before writing any code

name: Uniform Resource Identifier (URI)
definition: A string of characters used to identify a resource, such as a URL

name: Uniform Resource Locator (URL)
definition: A reference to a web resource that specifies its location on a computer network and a mechanism for retrieving it

name: Universally Unique Identifier (UUID)
definition: Unlike most other numbering schemes, this is for practical purposes unique, without depending for their uniqueness on a central registration authority or coordination between the parties generating them

name: User Experience (UX)
definition: The process of enhancing user satisfaction with a product by improving the usability, accessibility, and pleasure provided in the interaction with the product

name: User Interface (UI)
definition: The design users are provided to interact with a product or application

name: Web Graphics Library (WebGL)
definition: A JavaScript API for creating 2D and 3D graphics on the web

name: World Wide Web (www)
definition: An information space where documents and other web resources are identified by URLs, interlinked by hypertext links, and can be accessed via the Internet
